Award.AwardTitle: A Control-Systems Approach to Understanding Human Learning

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to understand how humans learn to control unknown dynamic systems. Humans possess exceptional learning capabilities that help them control complex systems with virtually no prior information. For example, humans ride bicycles, fly kites, and play with hula hoops. No existing control technique can match a human's ability to learn to interact with a wide variety of uncertain dynamic systems. This project addresses fundamental questions of human learning and control: What control strategies do humans learn? How do humans learn to control unknown dynamic systems? Understanding human learning has a high potential to transform a wide variety of technologies, such as human-interface devices and robotic-assist systems. For example, neurological injuries often lead to impaired motor control. Robotic-therapy devices have demonstrated some success in rehabilitation; however, improved understanding of human learning is necessary to unlock the potential of these technologies. As another example, learning to interact with complex systems, such as orthotic devices and haptic interfaces, can require significant training. Improved understanding of human learning will lead to interactive methods that accelerate learning.

The control strategies that humans learn and the processes used to learn them are currently unknown. The predominant human-learning theory in neuroscience is the "internal model" hypothesis, which proposes that humans construct and use models for control. However, evidence in support of the internal model hypothesis is inconclusive. This project offers a new approach to human-learning research that applies principles from control systems to address fundamental questions of human learning and control. Specifically, a series of human-subject-based experiments will be performed to study human learning. First, this project seeks to identify the strategies that humans employ to control dynamic systems. These experiments focus on identifying the strategies that humans use for systems with challenging characteristics, such as nonlinearities, instabilities, nonminimum-phase-zero dynamics, and high relative degree. A novel subsystem identification method will be used to mathematically model the controllers employed by the human subjects. Next, this project aims to identify the learning mechanisms that allow humans to adapt to and control unknown dynamic systems. Human learning mechanisms will be studied by examining how humans learn at different frequencies, by comparing human learning to adaptive control, and by exploring how humans use persistently exciting signals to learn.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to understand how humans learn to control dynamic systems. Humans possess exceptional learning capabilities that help them control complex dynamic systems. For example, humans learn to ride bicycles, fly airplanes, and operate cranes. No existing automatic control technique can match a human's ability to learn to interact with a wide variety of dynamic systems. This project addressed fundamental questions of human learning: How do humans learn to control dynamic systems? What control strategies do humans learn? What features make a system difficult for humans to control? Understanding human learning has a high potential to transform a wide variety of technologies, such as human-interface devices and robotic-assist systems.

The control strategies that humans learn and the processes used to learn them are currently unknown. One human-learning theory in neuroscience is the internal model hypothesis, which proposes that humans construct and use models for control. However, evidence in support of the internal model hypothesis is inconclusive and other theories have not been ruled out.

This project adopted a new approach to human-learning research that applies principles from control systems to address questions of human learning. In this project, we conducted human-in-the-loop (HITL) experiments with over 200 human subjects. Through a simulation environment, subjects interacted repeatedly (e.g., 40 trials) with different dynamic systems and performed a variety of different tasks (e.g., follow prescribed commands). Data from these experiments were used to address key human-learning questions.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes: One significant contribution of this project was the development of novel subsystem identification (SSID) algorithms that use data from HITL experiments to construct mathematical models of a human subject?s control strategy (feedback, feedforward, and time delay). These SSID algorithms were applied to data from the project?s HITL experiments.

The control-strategy models constructed from HITL data demonstrate that a key component of human learning is updating the anticipatory (i.e., feedforward) control until it approximates the inverse dynamics. Moreover, a crucial aspect of learning the inverse dynamics is learning to use phase lead in the anticipatory control. This result demonstrates a feedforward internal model. Results also demonstrate that humans? control behavior tends to become more linear with practice.

Another contribution of this work is the identification of characteristics that make dynamic systems difficult for humans to control. We conducted HITL experiments to examine the effects of system characteristics such as time delay, system zeros, relative degree, system order, phase lag, and nonlinearities. This work demonstrated that characteristics such as time delay, nonminimum-phase zeros, high relative degree, phase lag, and nonlinearities tend to make dynamic systems difficult for humans to learn to control. In particular, all of these characteristics tend to make it more difficult for humans? to learn to approximate the inverse dynamics in feedforward. This work also demonstrated that humans adapt to destabilizing changes in system time delay by altering their reactive (i.e., feedback) control to recover stability margins.

We also conducted HITL experiments to examine the effects of changing task (i.e., changing the command to be followed) and task preview (i.e., providing a subject with information about the future trajectory of a command). Experimental results show that the subjects are able to generalize a control strategy learned on one task to a different task. Results also suggest that subjects are able to learn without relying on prediction, but their ability to control a dynamic system without prediction is limited. Additionally, subjects? ability to perform a command-following task is significantly enhanced if they are provided with command preview. Notably, preview allows the subjects to compensate for and minimize sensory time delay in the feedforward path.

Broader Impacts Outcomes: This project resulted in an improved understanding of human learning, which has a high potential to advance control system technology and transform a variety technologies, such as human-interface devices and robotic-assist systems. This project?s new insights into human learning could advance control system technology by incorporating certain human-learning mechanisms into next-generation automatic control methods. Advancements in control systems technology will benefit a wide range of engineering applications (e.g., energy, automotive, aerospace, manufacturing, biomedical). The improved understanding of human learning accomplished through this project will also promote innovation in human interface technologies, such as, orthopedic devices, rehabilitation technologies, as well as the diagnosis and treatment of neuromotor disorders. For example, robotic-assisted treadmills are used to help patients with stroke, brain trauma, and spinal chord injuries learn to walk again.

This project created opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students to contribute to the field of human-learning research. This project provided training for 6 graduate students and one undergraduate student. This project also promoted participation, particularly from underrepresented groups, in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. For example, two female graduate students and one female undergraduate student participated in this project.
